thread.title: Fed expected to keep rates on hold
thread.title_full: Fed expected to keep rates on hold

title: Fed expected to keep rates on hold
text:
Soggy data cloud picture for divided Federal Reserve Sam Fleming in Washington ©Bloomberg 
The Federal Reserve is likely to leave interest rates unchanged this week while keeping its options open for its pivotal December meeting as it assesses signs of more muted growth in the US economy. 
The majority of Fed policymakers including chair Janet Yellen have said they expect the first upward move in the federal funds rate to happen this year, but the picture has become clouded in recent weeks because of slower hiring and a high-level policy split among the Fed’s governors . More Martin Sandbu's Free Lunch Mutiny at the Fed IN US Politics & Policy Clinton faces Benghazi questions 
Further complicating Fed calculations is the prospect of further stimulus by foreign central banks including the European Central Bank — something that could put added upward pressure on the dollar but also help global demand. 
The Federal Open Market Committee held fire on interest rates in September because of turbulent moves in global markets and fears the Chinese authorities were struggling to keep their economy on track. 
Economists surveyed by the Financial Times universally forecast no change on Wednesday given the short passage of time since the September meeting, meaning the market’s focus is now squarely on the Fed’s final policy meeting of 2015. 
“We believe Yellen’s objective will be to neither strongly signal a December hike nor to take that possibility off the table,” said Michael Feroli, US economist at JPMorgan Chase. 
Ms Yellen said in her September 17 press conference that the FOMC wanted to wait for further signs of job market strength to “bolster” its confidence that inflation was set to return to target. 
The data since then have failed to oblige, however. Momentum in hiring slowed in September and third-quarter gross domestic product growth is likely to decelerate to less than half the 3.9 per cent pace in the second quarter. Core inflation remains well below target. 
Although a pickup in wages is not a precondition for the Fed to move, officials are closely watching recent soggy numbers because they are indicative of the slack still in the labour market. With traders viewing the probability of a rise in December as well below 50 per cent, the data and Fed rhetoric will have to swing in a more positive direction to build expectations towards a rise on December 16. 
Policymakers appeared sharply divided going into this week’s meeting. Two Fed governors — Lael Brainard and Daniel Tarullo — took the unusual step of publicly distancing themselves from Ms Yellen’s recent analysis, signalling they are uncomfortable with the idea of raising rates this year. FTfm
